conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks a light source, and their size and position depend on the relative positions of the light source, object, and surface.
When the light source moves further away, the angle at which light rays hit objects changes, affecting shadow size and position.
As the light source moves further away, shadows become smaller because the light rays are less spread out.
Shadows move closer to the objects that cast them because the light rays hit the objects at a more direct angle.
Shadow A, cast by the birdcage, will become smaller and move closer to the birdcage.
Shadow B, a secondary shadow of the birdcage, will become smaller and move closer to the birdcage.
Shadow C, cast by the black cylindrical object, will become smaller and move closer to the object.
Shadow D, cast by the ornate object, will become smaller and move closer to the object.
Final answer: Shadows A, B, C, and D will all become smaller and move closer to their respective objects when the light source moves backwards.
